ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: anywhere from 1-10

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Professors, TA, presentations, structure.Weaknesses: This class is built for undergrads, not for public health students, which is extremely upsetting. The material is very basic if you have any knowledge of global health issues and at times it felt like more of an intro class at SOM than a strategic thinking class at YSPH.

This course is different to most others. You do not "learn" academically speaking, what you do learn are useful practical skills on the process of strategic problem solving, policy brief writing and group presentations. I think these are valuable skills that cannot but be helpful in whatever career path someone chooses.I only had one problem with the course. The undergraduates taking it were too many. They are conditioned here at Yale to speak up constantly and talk for long as they possibly can. Whilst some had interesting points to make, being concise is a skill they lack - and that is a useful skill for everyone too. Grad students were often annoyed by this and we wished lectures could go on with less interruption by the undergrads.

The weakness is the group project. Groups like mine put over 50 hours of prep into something that seemed like a farce in the end because of the "real world" antics the professors mount to try to ruffle you while you're presenting. For all the work we put in, would be nice to have an actual work product.LOTS OF UNDERGRADS. Would be great to have this course offered only for graduate students.Otherwise, good course.
Fantastic

Strengths:Learning the steps in strategic problem solving was a great experience with really beneficial lectures and wonderful guest speakers. The TA sessions was especially useful in applying lessons learned in class. Sarah was really great.Weakness:Undergraduates in the course. Working with undergraduates on a group project was difficult. One that I worked with was unorganized, showed up unprepared, and only wanted to meet late at night (10PM) and only near the main campus. When he/she did show up; was unprepared. The final week before presentation he/she wanted to take full responsibility of the project, and was very disrespectful of others input and time. There was a lot of wasted time (a lot) that could have been used more effectively.

It gave me a clear understanding of the steps toward good policy formation and writing policy briefs and how that plays out in the global context.Some lectures were a bit tedious and I thought over simple for the concepts that were trying to be relayed.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Awesome
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Dr Bradley is AMAZING, it was so great to be in her class and learn from her.
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Can't say enough. She's great.
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  great
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Excellent

Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Betsy is fantastic and always seems to convey exactly the point that needs to be brought up from her analysis of group presentations to how she presents her lecture material.
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Awesome
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Great!
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Amazing.
Instructor: Leslie Curry  great
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Excellent
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Warm, energetic and always smiling, it was hard not to pay attention to what she said and she did so in a clear, easily understandable way.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Awesome
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Great and very nice!
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  His lectures were too elementary, but he's responsive to students and a strength for the course.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  great
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Excellent

Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Easy going and helpful, Mike brought a lot of expertise from his previous work in DC to some of the discussions. I felt at times he was uncomfortable lecturing to the class but overall was good.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Sarah was great.
Sarah Pallas was a great TA, really took an interest in us and was extremely helpful. I'm sure she will be a great professor soon. Thanks Sarah!

Sarah clearly put a lot of effort into TAing this course and did a great job. A few times in section, she spoke to students in a way that made me uncomfortable (maybe she got a bit defensive?), but other than that, she was a great help and always available.
Sarah is fantastic
Sarah Pallas: great job, gave valuable input in our group projects.
Sarah was great. She was always available by email and flexible with her office hours. It wasa real benefit having her as a TA.

Sarah was fantastic. She went the extra mile in bringing up important topics in the discussion section. I always felt like she was on our side in helping us get through the difficult assignments even going so far as to come into school on a Saturday evening to hear our group give our presentation and stick around past when she said she needed to leave to give feedback.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a great course to learn practical skills on strategic problem solving. I found the undergrad participation to be somewhat distracting, but overall I enjoyed it and would definitely recommend it for anyone, as these skills can be applied to all career options.
If you can stand a class that is a majority of brilliant, Yale College kids, take it. If that makes you shutter (especially considering the LARGE amount of group work involved), skip it.
I highly recommend this course

Gives a nice overview of topics in global health and concepts in strategic thinking, but the real value here comes from interaction with other students and the amazing professors. The ongoing writing assignment was fine but not an incredible learning experience (since I have taken other courses with a focus on strategic thinking), but the groupprojects and particularly the group presentations were incredibly valuable as someone going into this field. The professors are amazingly open and friendly.
I would recommend this course because the strategy methods taught and the professors were excellent but I would be wary of taking a class that involves a group project with undergraduates.
I feel it is a worthwhile course. I felt at times it was hard having both grad students and undergrads in the class but at times that was also a benefit.
